awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Indigenous Rights, Cultural Politics, and the Gaps Between International and Domestic Law
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will focus on reasons for and impacts of delays in the implementation of recommendations from an international court of human rights to expropriate land to honor land claims of indigenous communities as restitution for human rights violations.  The doctoral student will conduct case studies of three different court rulings to answer three general sets of questions:  (1) What factors have led to the implementation delays, and why do they continue in all three cases?  (2) How do claimant community members perceive the experience of fighting for territory from the state and its effect on their cultural identity and political power?  (3) How do the indigenous communities, private landowners, and state agencies involved in the claims process articulate and perform territory as a concept and in practice?  The project findings will contribute to theoretical debates in the fields of political economy, legal geography, and cultural geography regarding the performance of law and territory, multiculturalism, and indigenous rights.  The project will add new insights to lines of inquiry in which territory is not viewed as synonymous with a specific political jurisdiction but instead is viewed as a form of spatial organization made from political, economic, legal, and cultural activities where resource control is at stake, power relations are dynamic, and new cultural identities and political subjectivities are created.  The project will enhance international collaborative relationships and will build capacity by providing training in community-based mapping methods for members of indigenous communities.  The project's findings will be shared with representatives of the international court and with communities engaged in the disputes.  Although focusing on a specific set of case studies, the insights and information obtained in this study of legal processes and their impact on the territoriality of people will have relevance to a broad range of other locales where restitution of land is an approach aimed to try to redress wrongs that have been committed in the past.  As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

The doctoral student will conduct this research by focusing on three specific rulings issued by the Inter-American Court of Human Rights to expropriate land as restitution for human rights violations against indigenous peoples in Paraguay.  The student will employ a mixed-methods qualitative approach that includes semi-structured interviews, participant observation, archival research, and community-based mapping.  Among those involved in the project are leaders and other members of the indigenous communities that have made and won their claims, representatives from government institutions, lawyers, representatives from nongovernmental organizations and academics involved in the process, and the owners of the lands to be expropriated.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement grant “Indigenous Rights, Cultural Politics, and the Gaps Between International and Domestic Law” (project #1459366) was used to support a 12-month investigation into the impacts and politics of Inter-American Court of Human Rights cases on the rights of Indigenous peoples in Paraguay. The study centered on three landmark cases regarding relationships between Indigenous land rights and human rights violations in the Sawhoyamaxa, Yakye Axa, Xákmok Kásek, and Kelyenmagategma cases (the latter being a case resolved by a friendly settlement achieved through Inter-American Commission on Human Rights). The Co-PI used a suite of qualitative methods to generate data based on the research design; these methods include: 100 semi-structured and informal interviews, community-based participatory mapping, policy analysis and archival studies, complemented by months of participant observation of daily life in affected Indigenous communities, legal negotiations, and political mobilizing.

The findings of this research project advance numerous intellectual debates in geography and the social sciences. The primary intellectual significance of the study centers on questions about: 1) the limits of multicultural policy Indigenous rights in practice and the prospects for creating more inclusive societies based on such policy; 2) the reach and effects of the so-called “territorial turn” related to recent trends in recognizing Indigenous territorial rights across the Americas; 3) the effects of international Indigenous rights legal mechanisms on national political issues; and 4) environmental racism, environmental justice, and nature-society relationships embodied in Indigenous struggles for rights and recognition in the context of settler societies and broad agrarian change. As a result, the Co-PI elaborated the first in-depth comparative ethnographic study to date about the effects of Inter-American Court of Human Rights rulings on the practice of Indigenous rights, particularly those to land. Thus, this research project makes important theoretical and empirical contributions to knowledge that inform, and are useful for, academics, practitioners, and the Indigenous communities who collaborated on this research project among others who are involved in similar legal struggles.

Although the project has recently closed, outcomes to date have been significant and broad. First, per the study design and interests of research collaborators in the involved Indigenous communities, the Co-PI facilitated community-based mapping projects and taught 34 Indigenous peoples how to use open-source geospatial technologies and/or community mapping techniques to support and strengthen their land claims. These skills are currently being used by study participants to advance Indigenous land rights in communities outside those directly involved in this research project. Second, the Co-PI has presented preliminary findings from this project to international Indigenous rights lawyers and practitioners from Paraguay, Kenya, Tanzania, Nigeria, Malaysia, France, England, and the United States. As such, some of the findings have influenced high-level international Indigenous land rights policy analysis that will be presented at the 2017 meeting of the United Nations Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues. Some study results have already been shared with the UN Special Rapporteur on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples as well as with the Co-PI’s research collaborators from the affected communities involved with this study and Indigenous rights activists and practitioners in the country. Third, the Co-PI has presented findings from this research at two international academic conferences to date and is scheduled to share study results with diverse group of academics and practitioners at six inter-disciplinary domestic and international workshops, conferences and invited lectures in the United States and Latin America during 2017. Moreover, the Co-PI is currently preparing two articles that will be submitted for publication in peer-reviewed academic journals in 2017 and writing his doctoral dissertation. Fourth, and finally, the Co-PI is drawing from this research to educate students about Indigenous rights at the University-level. He has used findings from this study to inform and design classes that he teaches and is therefore helping students understand the importance and gravity of issues facing many Indigenous communities across the Americas in relation to, self-determination, political inclusion, the right to cultural practice, and resource struggles. In conclusion, the broad outcomes and impacts realized to date coupled with the intellectual significance of this research project ensure the lasting reach and importance of this study.
